frameDefinitions: These words describe the size of message that a Speaker is judged by a (usually unexpressed)
An Entity is judged by a sound Attribute of some perceived level of Volume intensity.
An Entity stands out perceptually in comparison to other members of its type.

The words in this frame have to do with a Speaker asking an Addressee a question which calls for a reply (as opposed to making a request which calls for an action on the part of the Addressee).  '' 'We asked Ruby what kind of food they ate.'
This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication.
The adjectives and nouns in this frame are all based on the idea that mental properties may be attributed to a person (Protagonist) by a (usually implicit)
frameExamples: Graham is very shy with most people, but he gets very <t>chatty</t> with Mr. Roberts.
Pilot Mountain in NC is very <t>prominent</t>.
We <t>asked</t> Ruby what kind of food they ate.
Evelyn was <t>candid</t> with me about the party.
It was <t>stupid</t> of me to do that.
listRoleDefinitions: This is the person who is characterized as talkative, reticent etc.  It is usually the External Argument:

<fen>Text</fen> is rarely expressed because the quantity of information given is the focus of the frame, rather than the information content. Texts can occur as NP objects, but cannot be either direct quotes or complement clauses.
This role is the <fen>Topic</fen> on which much or little information is communicated. <fen>Topic</fen> is far more frequent than Message in this frame.
The <fen>Entity</fen> for which the sound level <fen>Attribute</fen> is under consideration.
The feature of an <fen>Entity</fen> which is under consideration. This role is incorporated in each LU in the frame.
A quantity or characterization of the <fen>Entity</fen>'s sound output with repspect to its <fen>Attribute</fen>.
A modifier expressing the deviation of the <fen>Volume</fen> from the norm.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Entity</fen> is in the state of having  a particular <fen>Volume</fen> for the <fen>Attribute</fen>.
The place where an <fen>Entity</fen> is located.
The <fen>Entity</fen> for which the saliency <fen>Attribute</fen> is appropriate and under consideration.
The feature of the <fen>Entity</fen> which is under discussion, namely perceptual salience.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Entity</fen> is in the state of having  a particular salience.
This role refers to the location where the <fen>Entity</fen> has a prominence of some <fen>Attribute</fen>.
The person asking a question generally occurs as the External Argument of verb and noun targets:

The Addressee is most frequently the NP Object of a target verb.  However, with the verb <ment>inquire</ment>, Addressee can only occur as an <ment>of</ment>-PP and with a noun target, Addressee occurs in a PP Complement or as a possessive :
The Message, or content of the question, usually takes the form of a direct quote or an embedded question with a verb target:
Topic occurs very frequently in this frame with both noun and verb targets. It generally occurs as a PP Complement:
The time at which the questioning occurs.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Message</fen>, the truth or sincerity of which is at issue. It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word, or as the Nominal Head of prenominal uses.

<fen>Message</fen> is the communicative content whose truth or sincerity is at issue. This role does not normally co-occur with the other FEs in this frame. When it does occur, it is normally the External Argument of a predicative use of the <t>Target</t> word, or the modified Nominal Head in a prenominal use.

The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It often occurs without the <fen>Message</fen> role in predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about'.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.

This is the person (or people) to whom a mental property is attributed. The role may be expressed as External Argument of a predicative use of the adjective, as a PP Complement, or as the head noun modified by an attributive use of the adjective:

The <fen>Behavior</fen> refers to any action, utterance, belief, or artifact thereof on the basis of which a mental property is attributed to the <fen>Protagonist</fen>. The meaning of the English word <ment>behavior</ment> should not be taken to constrain the identity of this frame element too much---conceptually, this frame element includes things that would not normally be described using the word <ment>behavior</ment>.  Note the following examples:

Some of the words in this frame have a slightly different use in that they evaluate someone only with respect to their mental performance in some particular domain or capacity.  We call this domain or capacity <t>Practice</t>. E.g., She is <t>astute</t> <fex name='Practice'>at math</fex>. Note that this does not mean she is considered to be astute in general for doing math. Rather, she is astute with respect to math, but may be dumb with respect to other things. These uses probably belong in a different frame with words such as <ment>skilled</ment>, but for the time being they are marked with the role Practice. General Grammatical Observations:  The adjectives in this frame may exhibit Extraposition of a <ment>to</ment>-marked infinitive VP, with an optional Protagonist expressed in an <ment>of</ment>-PP: It was <t>brilliant</t> (of you) <fex name='Prac'>to invite the clowns to the party</fex>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Pat</fex> has been silent on this issue.
Kim is very talkative <fex>about her family and childhood</fex>.
If you are asked to search for the plus sign with red-vertical and green-horizontal elements, <fex>all the red and green plus signs</fex> may seem to become salient.
The diagram, (a frequency distribution chart) shows a <fex>prominently</fex> conspicuous region of stars that extend from the extremely bright and hot stars to the faint and cool variety.
The affection for American culture seemed more prominent <fex>last year</fex>.
<fex>Pat</fex> quizzed me about where I had been.
Pat questioned <fex>me</fex> about where I had been.
Evelyn made some candid remarks <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>You</fex> were smart to save all your receipts.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts
